titleStmt.title: M54, 11 of 11. [Anon: there is a jolt at the points...]. Typescript fragment, 1 fol.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M54, 11 of 11. [Anon: there is a jolt at the points...]. Typescript fragment, 1 fol.

N.B.: This is one of eleven sub-fragments identified in the Berg Collection's M54. [Anon: The printing press brought the past into existence...]. Typescript fragments, unsigned and undated, 35 fols. I have determined pagination and sequencing based on subject matter. M54 as curated by the Berg Collection is available as part of 'The Digital Anon' and can be found at [LINK].

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p: there is a jolt at the points; the mind slides onto another rail, lovely as the words are. To speak them the poet has separated himself from the actors. He cannot yet make speak those words. The play is still manly (mainly) the work of the undifferentiated audience, demanding great names, great deeds; simple outlines; and not the single subtlety of one soul.

For the play itself was still anonymous. The lack of Marlowes name is by itslef (itself) enough to show how largely the play was a common product, written by one hand, but so moulded in transition from actor to acotr (actor) that the author had no sense of property in it. It was half the work of the audience. Yet the audience is dumb. The silence of the audience is one of the deep gulfs that lies between us and the Eliza (Elizabethan) bethan (Elizabethan) play. The audience was a large one. Fifteen hundred people, Dr Greg computes, was an average attanedance (attendance). Their presence, in the penny part of the house, is obvious. It draws pup (up) the hypberpole (hyperbole) as a sheet of paper draws pup (up) fire. It makes the writer capable of great strides and vast audacities beyond his private reach. Yet the audiene (audience) sits silent.

To underdtand (understand) the silence we must comapre (compare) it with our own attidtue (attitude) at the at the in the early days. A new art comes upon us si (so) surprisningly (surprisingly) that we are silent, recognising something that we cannot measure. To the Elizabethans, the power of words after their long silnce (silence) must have been overwhelming. There at the or at the men and women who had never seen themselves whose only reading was historyor (history or) sermon or some old chornicle (chronicle) or perhaps could not r ad (read) but spent all their days in the
